docs.text: Welcome to pyepidemics documentation ¶ Open-source epidemics modeling Python library pyepidemics is a Python library to easily manipulate epidemiological models (SIR, SEIR, COVID19), forecast, and test policy scenarios. Main features are: Creation of classical compartmental models (SIR, SEIR, SEIDR, etc...) Creation of COVID19 related model (with ICU and different levels of symptoms) Creation of custom compartmental model Easy extend to compartmental model on different levels (by age, by region, by age and region, etc...) Implementation of contact matrices Implementation of policies (lockdown, tracing, testing, etc...) Calibration of epidemiological parameters on real-world data using Bayesian optimization Data helpers to get up-to-date data (cases, beds availability, population contact matrices) (NB as of today only for France cases) Simple curve fitting algorithms Economics modeling on consumption and production Warning This library is under active development, please contact Théo Alves Da Costa if you need more information and would like to contribute Contributors ¶ The library has been initially developed by Ekimetrics under the coalition of French AI companies CoData or help French government response to the COVID19 pandemics. Main contributors are: Théo Alves Da Costa , Ekimetrics Léo Grosjean, Ekimetrics Pierre Carles, Ekimetrics Nicolas Chesneau, Ekimetrics Marianne Chehade, Ekimetrics Jean-Baptiste Remy
docs.title: Welcome to pyepidemics documentation

docs.text: Open-source epidemics modeling Python library pyepidemics is a Python library to easily manipulate epidemiological models (SIR, SEIR, COVID19), forecast, and test policy scenarios. Main features are: Creation of classical compartmental models (SIR, SEIR, SEIDR, etc...) Creation of COVID19 related model (with ICU and different levels of symptoms) Creation of custom compartmental model Easy extend to compartmental model on different levels (by age, by region, by age and region, etc...) Implementation of contact matrices Implementation of policies (lockdown, tracing, testing, etc...) Calibration of epidemiological parameters on real-world data using Bayesian optimization Data helpers to get up-to-date data (cases, beds availability, population contact matrices) (NB as of today only for France cases) Simple curve fitting algorithms Economics modeling on consumption and production Warning This library is under active development, please contact Théo Alves Da Costa if you need more information and would like to contribute

Main contributors are: Théo Alves Da Costa , Ekimetrics Léo Grosjean, Ekimetrics Pierre Carles, Ekimetrics Nicolas Chesneau, Ekimetrics Marianne Chehade, Ekimetrics Jean-Baptiste Remy
docs.title: Contributors

docs.text: Quickstart ¶ Creating a SIR model ¶ # Import library from pyepidemics.models import SIR # Let's take approximate parameters during COVID19 epidemics N = 67e6 beta = 3.3 / 4 gamma = 1 / 4 # Instantiate model with epidemiological parameters sir = SIR ( N , beta , gamma ) # Solve for one infected case for 100 days starting from 2020-01-24 states = sir . solve ( 1 , n_days = 100 , start_date = "2020-01-24" ) # Visualize epidemic curves using matplotlib (plotly available) states . show ( plotly = False ) Creating a custom compartmental model ¶ Here is the example to create a model like the SIR described above from pyepidemics.models import CompartmentalModel class SIR ( CompartmentalModel ): def __init__ ( self , N , beta , gamma ): # Define compartments name and number compartments = [ "S" , "I" , "R" ] super () . __init__ ( compartments ) # Parameters self . N = N # Total population self . beta = beta # How many person each person infects per day self . gamma = gamma # Rate of infection, duration = 1/gamma # Add transition self . add_transition ( "S" , "I" , lambda y , t : self . beta * y [ "S" ] * y [ "I" ] / self . N ) self . add_transition ( "I" , "R" , lambda y , t : self . gamma * y [ "I" ])
docs.title: Quickstart

docs.text: # Import library from pyepidemics.models import SIR # Let's take approximate parameters during COVID19 epidemics N = 67e6 beta = 3.3 / 4 gamma = 1 / 4 # Instantiate model with epidemiological parameters sir = SIR ( N , beta , gamma ) # Solve for one infected case for 100 days starting from 2020-01-24 states = sir . solve ( 1 , n_days = 100 , start_date = "2020-01-24" ) # Visualize epidemic curves using matplotlib (plotly available) states . show ( plotly = False )
docs.title: Creating a SIR model

docs.text: Here is the example to create a model like the SIR described above from pyepidemics.models import CompartmentalModel class SIR ( CompartmentalModel ): def __init__ ( self , N , beta , gamma ): # Define compartments name and number compartments = [ "S" , "I" , "R" ] super () . __init__ ( compartments ) # Parameters self . N = N # Total population self . beta = beta # How many person each person infects per day self . gamma = gamma # Rate of infection, duration = 1/gamma # Add transition self . add_transition ( "S" , "I" , lambda y , t : self . beta * y [ "S" ] * y [ "I" ] / self . N ) self . add_transition ( "I" , "R" , lambda y , t : self . gamma * y [ "I" ])
docs.title: Creating a custom compartmental model

docs.text: (function() { function addWidgetsRenderer() { var mimeElement = document.querySelector('script[type="application/vnd.jupyter.widget-view+json"]'); var scriptElement = document.createElement('script'); var widgetRendererSrc = 'https://unpkg.com/@jupyter-widgets/html-manager@*/dist/embed-amd.js'; var widgetState; // Fallback for older version: try { widgetState = mimeElement && JSON.parse(mimeElement.innerHTML); if (widgetState && (widgetState.version_major < 2 || !widgetState.version_major)) { widgetRendererSrc = 'jupyter-js-widgets@*/dist/embed.js'; } } catch(e) {} scriptElement.src = widgetRendererSrc; document.body.appendChild(scriptElement); } document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', addWidgetsRenderer); }()); Curve fitting tutorial ¶ Note Curve fitting is the simple process of finding a surrogate function approximating a system dynamics, ie curve fitting. For example in epidemiology, cumulative deaths grow slowly at first, accelerate when the epidemics is at the peak and slows down to reach a plateau, this can be approximated using a logistic function. # Base Data Science snippet import pandas as pd import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import os import time from tqdm import tqdm_notebook % matplotlib inline % load_ext autoreload % autoreload 2 # Developer import import sys sys . path . append ( "../" ) The autoreload extension is already loaded. To reload it, use: %reload_ext autoreload import pyepidemics Introduction ¶ Introduction to curve fitting ¶ Epidemic curves often follow a particular shape : Cumulative deaths reach a plateau, we could approximate it with a logistic curve Infections, stay in hospital, often reach a peak before declining, we could approximate it with a gaussian or skewed gaussian curve This is what curve fitting is about, once we have a surrogate function approximating the epidemic curve we can make predictions. Yet it only works under the assumption that the situation is constant which is totally unrealistic. However even if the model is wrong, that does not mean is not useful, curve fitting can easily be used at scale on many countries or used to capture the dynamics of epidemics curve to better calibrate compartmental models Getting some data ¶ from pyepidemics.dataset import fetch_daily_case_france cases = fetch_daily_case_france () cases [[ "D" , "H" , "ICU" ]] . plot ( figsize = ( 15 , 4 ), title = "COVID19 cases (D=Dead,H=Hospital,ICU)" ) plt . show () Curve fitting in practice ¶ from pyepidemics.curve_fitting import logistic_fn , gaussian_fn from pyepidemics.curve_fitting import CurveFittingModel Surrogate functions ¶ Logistic function ¶ A logistic function is useful to represent system dynamics reaching a plateau after an inflexion. More on the wikipedia page https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_function Formula is : f(x)=\frac{a}{1+e^{-k(x - \mu)}} f(x)=\frac{a}{1+e^{-k(x - \mu)}} We can use the fonction pyepidemics.curve_fitting.logistic_fn(x,a,mu,k) # Take x between 0 and 100 x = np . linspace ( 0 , 100 ) # Prepare plot plt . figure ( figsize = ( 15 , 4 )) # Plot many functions for k in [ 0.05 , 0.1 , 0.2 , 0.5 , 1 ]: plt . plot ( logistic_fn ( x , k = k , a = 10 , mu = 50 ), label = f "k={k}" ) # Display figure plt . title ( "Logistic functions" ) plt . legend () plt . show () Gaussian function ¶ Formula is : f(x)=a e^{-0.5(\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma})^2} f(x)=a e^{-0.5(\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma})^2} We can use the fonction pyepidemics.curve_fitting.gaussian_fn(x,a,mu,sigma) # Take x between 0 and 100 x = np . linspace ( 0 , 100 ) # Prepare plot plt . figure ( figsize = ( 15 , 4 )) # Plot many functions for sigma in [ 5 , 10 , 20 ]: plt . plot ( gaussian_fn ( x , sigma = sigma , a = 10 , mu = 50 ), label = f "sigma={sigma}" ) # Display figure plt . title ( "Gaussian functions" ) plt . legend () plt . show () Fitting surrogate functions to COVID cases ¶ We will use the CurveFittingModel which merely wraps curve_fit function from scipy in a scikit learn fashion. from pyepidemics.curve_fitting import CurveFittingModel Fitting the death cases ¶ Let's start by fitting the death cases with a logistic function model = CurveFittingModel ( "logistic" ) Fitting returns the parameters a,mu,k of the logistics function model . fit ( cases [ "D" ]) array([1.75350267e+04, 7.87308460e+01, 1.16910544e-01]) Let's predict for 20 days after the date and visualize the fit pred = model . predict ( 20 , show_fit = True ) Fitting the ICU cases with gaussian curve ¶ model = CurveFittingModel ( "gaussian" ) pred = model . fit_predict ( cases [ "ICU" ], show_fit = True ) It works ok, but actually ICU cases are not a proper gaussian curve, we have a step ascend in the number of cases, and a slower decline. Hence what we need here could simply be a skewed guassian model = CurveFittingModel ( "skewed_gaussian" ) pred = model . fit_predict ( cases [ "ICU" ], show_fit = True ) Now we have a much better fit Advanced users ¶ There are a few details you can use as an advanced user, deep dive into the code internals to learn more : You can specify the initial parameters p0 of the curve fitting optimization freely by passing p0 argument to the fit or fit_predict function. Actually for the gaussian functions those initial parameters are automatically inferred from the dataset provided to facilitate convergence. You can actually specify any function to fit in the curve fitting model as shown below Fitting a custom function ¶ Let's create a fake dataset with a simple linear function # Preparing the true function and the function with noise example_fn = lambda x , a , b : a * x + b example_fn_random = lambda x , a , b : example_fn ( x , a , b ) + np . random . randn ( len ( x )) * 2 # Parameter we want to estimate a = 2 b = 1 # Creating fake dataset x = np . linspace ( 0 , 20 ) y = example_fn_random ( x , a , b ) # Visualizing fake dataset plt . figure ( figsize = ( 15 , 4 )) plt . scatter ( x , y ) plt . show () And here we are, we have a Linear Regression model model = CurveFittingModel ( example_fn ) pred = model . fit_predict ( y ) # Visualizing fake dataset plt . figure ( figsize = ( 15 , 4 )) plt . scatter ( x , y ) plt . plot ( x , pred ) plt . show ()
docs.title: Curve fitting

docs.text: Note Curve fitting is the simple process of finding a surrogate function approximating a system dynamics, ie curve fitting. For example in epidemiology, cumulative deaths grow slowly at first, accelerate when the epidemics is at the peak and slows down to reach a plateau, this can be approximated using a logistic function. # Base Data Science snippet import pandas as pd import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import os import time from tqdm import tqdm_notebook % matplotlib inline % load_ext autoreload % autoreload 2 # Developer import import sys sys . path . append ( "../" ) The autoreload extension is already loaded. To reload it, use: %reload_ext autoreload import pyepidemics

docs.text: Epidemic curves often follow a particular shape : Cumulative deaths reach a plateau, we could approximate it with a logistic curve Infections, stay in hospital, often reach a peak before declining, we could approximate it with a gaussian or skewed gaussian curve This is what curve fitting is about, once we have a surrogate function approximating the epidemic curve we can make predictions. Yet it only works under the assumption that the situation is constant which is totally unrealistic. However even if the model is wrong, that does not mean is not useful, curve fitting can easily be used at scale on many countries or used to capture the dynamics of epidemics curve to better calibrate compartmental models
docs.title: Introduction to curve fitting

docs.text: A logistic function is useful to represent system dynamics reaching a plateau after an inflexion. More on the wikipedia page https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_function Formula is : f(x)=\frac{a}{1+e^{-k(x - \mu)}} f(x)=\frac{a}{1+e^{-k(x - \mu)}} We can use the fonction pyepidemics.curve_fitting.logistic_fn(x,a,mu,k) # Take x between 0 and 100 x = np . linspace ( 0 , 100 ) # Prepare plot plt . figure ( figsize = ( 15 , 4 )) # Plot many functions for k in [ 0.05 , 0.1 , 0.2 , 0.5 , 1 ]: plt . plot ( logistic_fn ( x , k = k , a = 10 , mu = 50 ), label = f "k={k}" ) # Display figure plt . title ( "Logistic functions" ) plt . legend () plt . show ()

docs.text: We will use the CurveFittingModel which merely wraps curve_fit function from scipy in a scikit learn fashion. from pyepidemics.curve_fitting import CurveFittingModel
docs.title: Fitting surrogate functions to COVID cases

docs.text: Let's start by fitting the death cases with a logistic function model = CurveFittingModel ( "logistic" ) Fitting returns the parameters a,mu,k of the logistics function model . fit ( cases [ "D" ]) array([1.75350267e+04, 7.87308460e+01, 1.16910544e-01]) Let's predict for 20 days after the date and visualize the fit pred = model . predict ( 20 , show_fit = True )
docs.title: Fitting the death cases

docs.text: model = CurveFittingModel ( "gaussian" ) pred = model . fit_predict ( cases [ "ICU" ], show_fit = True ) It works ok, but actually ICU cases are not a proper gaussian curve, we have a step ascend in the number of cases, and a slower decline. Hence what we need here could simply be a skewed guassian model = CurveFittingModel ( "skewed_gaussian" ) pred = model . fit_predict ( cases [ "ICU" ], show_fit = True ) Now we have a much better fit
docs.title: Fitting the ICU cases with gaussian curve

docs.text: There are a few details you can use as an advanced user, deep dive into the code internals to learn more : You can specify the initial parameters p0 of the curve fitting optimization freely by passing p0 argument to the fit or fit_predict function. Actually for the gaussian functions those initial parameters are automatically inferred from the dataset provided to facilitate convergence. You can actually specify any function to fit in the curve fitting model as shown below
docs.title: Advanced users

docs.text: Let's create a fake dataset with a simple linear function # Preparing the true function and the function with noise example_fn = lambda x , a , b : a * x + b example_fn_random = lambda x , a , b : example_fn ( x , a , b ) + np . random . randn ( len ( x )) * 2 # Parameter we want to estimate a = 2 b = 1 # Creating fake dataset x = np . linspace ( 0 , 20 ) y = example_fn_random ( x , a , b ) # Visualizing fake dataset plt . figure ( figsize = ( 15 , 4 )) plt . scatter ( x , y ) plt . show () And here we are, we have a Linear Regression model model = CurveFittingModel ( example_fn ) pred = model . fit_predict ( y ) # Visualizing fake dataset plt . figure ( figsize = ( 15 , 4 )) plt . scatter ( x , y ) plt . plot ( x , pred ) plt . show ()
docs.title: Fitting a custom function

docs.text: (function() { function addWidgetsRenderer() { var mimeElement = document.querySelector('script[type="application/vnd.jupyter.widget-view+json"]'); var scriptElement = document.createElement('script'); var widgetRendererSrc = 'https://unpkg.com/@jupyter-widgets/html-manager@*/dist/embed-amd.js'; var widgetState; // Fallback for older version: try { widgetState = mimeElement && JSON.parse(mimeElement.innerHTML); if (widgetState && (widgetState.version_major < 2 || !widgetState.version_major)) { widgetRendererSrc = 'jupyter-js-widgets@*/dist/embed.js'; } } catch(e) {} scriptElement.src = widgetRendererSrc; document.body.appendChild(scriptElement); } document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', addWidgetsRenderer); }()); Creating a custom compartmental model ¶ Note You may want to create a custom compartmental model to finetune COVID19 analysis or realize models for new diseases. This tutorial will guide you through this creation. # Base Data Science snippet import pandas as pd import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import os import time from tqdm import tqdm_notebook % matplotlib inline % load_ext autoreload % autoreload 2 # Developer import import sys sys . path . append ( "../../" ) The autoreload extension is already loaded. To reload it, use: %reload_ext autoreload import pyepidemics Creating a SIR model with new born ¶ Starting from a simple SIR model ¶ from pyepidemics.models import CompartmentalModel class SIR ( CompartmentalModel ): def __init__ ( self , N , beta , gamma ): # Define compartments name and number compartments = [ "S" , "I" , "R" ] super () . __init__ ( compartments ) # Parameters self . N = N # Total population # Add transition self . add_transition ( "S" , "I" , lambda y , t : beta * y [ "S" ] * y [ "I" ] / self . N ) self . add_transition ( "I" , "R" , lambda y , t : gamma * y [ "I" ]) N = 67e6 beta = 3.3 / 4 gamma = 1 / 4 sir = SIR ( N , beta , gamma ) states = sir . solve ( n_days = 100 ) states . show ( plotly = False ) Adding a new born compartment ¶ class NSIR ( CompartmentalModel ): def __init__ ( self , N , beta , gamma , birth_rate , susceptibility_rate ): # Define compartments name and number compartments = [ "N" , "S" , "I" , "R" ] super () . __init__ ( compartments , initial_state = "S" , start_state = "I" ) # Parameters self . N = N # Total population # Add transition self . add_static_derivative ( "N" , lambda y , t : birth_rate ) self . add_transition ( "N" , "S" , lambda y , t : susceptibility_rate * y [ "N" ]) self . add_transition ( "S" , "I" , lambda y , t : beta * y [ "S" ] * y [ "I" ] / self . N ) self . add_transition ( "I" , "R" , lambda y , t : gamma * y [ "I" ]) N = 1000 beta = 1 / 10 # 1 child is contaminated every 10 days gamma = 1 / 30 # You recover in 30 days birth_rate = 1 # 1 child is born per day susceptibility_rate = 1 / 30 # a child become susceptible in 20 days nsir = NSIR ( N , beta , gamma , birth_rate , susceptibility_rate ) states = nsir . solve ( n_days = 1000 ) states . show ( plotly = False ) Modelling Fox & Rabbit populations ¶ Such models can also be used to model the dynamics of any deterministic system. For example if you want to model the famous predator-prey model, aka Fox&Rabbit model, aka Lotka-Volterra competition problem you can also use the pyepidemics library as shown below : class LotkaVolterra ( CompartmentalModel ): def __init__ ( self , alpha , beta , gamma , delta ): # Define compartments name and number compartments = [ "fox" , "rabbit" ] super () . __init__ ( compartments ) # Add transition self . add_static_derivative ( "rabbit" , lambda y , t : alpha * y [ "rabbit" ] - beta * y [ "rabbit" ] * y [ "fox" ]) self . add_static_derivative ( "fox" , lambda y , t : beta * delta * y [ "rabbit" ] * y [ "fox" ] - gamma * y [ "fox" ] ) alpha = 1. beta = 0.1 gamma = 1.5 delta = 0.75 lotka = LotkaVolterra ( alpha , beta , delta , gamma ) states = lotka . solve ( n_days = 30 , init_state = { "rabbit" : 10 , "fox" : 5 }, d = 100 ) states . show ( plotly = False ) Advanced users ¶ There are many other parameters you can configure in custom models: I0 , the number of infected at t = 0 start_date to deal with dates and not days initial_state and start_state , start means at which state the epidemics start, for a SIR model initial_state="S" and start_state="I" Super-advanced users ¶ Overriding derivatives: Behind the CompartmentalModel a network is constructed and derivatives are computed using network transitions. Yet for any model you could override Adding granularity: to build models by categories (age, region) using contact matrix, it's also easy to build with pyepidemics
docs.title: Creating a custom model

docs.text: Note You may want to create a custom compartmental model to finetune COVID19 analysis or realize models for new diseases. This tutorial will guide you through this creation. # Base Data Science snippet import pandas as pd import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import os import time from tqdm import tqdm_notebook % matplotlib inline % load_ext autoreload % autoreload 2 # Developer import import sys sys . path . append ( "../../" ) The autoreload extension is already loaded. To reload it, use: %reload_ext autoreload import pyepidemics
docs.title: Creating a custom compartmental model
Creating a SIR model with new born

docs.text: from pyepidemics.models import CompartmentalModel class SIR ( CompartmentalModel ): def __init__ ( self , N , beta , gamma ): # Define compartments name and number compartments = [ "S" , "I" , "R" ] super () . __init__ ( compartments ) # Parameters self . N = N # Total population # Add transition self . add_transition ( "S" , "I" , lambda y , t : beta * y [ "S" ] * y [ "I" ] / self . N ) self . add_transition ( "I" , "R" , lambda y , t : gamma * y [ "I" ]) N = 67e6 beta = 3.3 / 4 gamma = 1 / 4 sir = SIR ( N , beta , gamma ) states = sir . solve ( n_days = 100 ) states . show ( plotly = False )
docs.title: Starting from a simple SIR model

docs.text: class NSIR ( CompartmentalModel ): def __init__ ( self , N , beta , gamma , birth_rate , susceptibility_rate ): # Define compartments name and number compartments = [ "N" , "S" , "I" , "R" ] super () . __init__ ( compartments , initial_state = "S" , start_state = "I" ) # Parameters self . N = N # Total population # Add transition self . add_static_derivative ( "N" , lambda y , t : birth_rate ) self . add_transition ( "N" , "S" , lambda y , t : susceptibility_rate * y [ "N" ]) self . add_transition ( "S" , "I" , lambda y , t : beta * y [ "S" ] * y [ "I" ] / self . N ) self . add_transition ( "I" , "R" , lambda y , t : gamma * y [ "I" ]) N = 1000 beta = 1 / 10 # 1 child is contaminated every 10 days gamma = 1 / 30 # You recover in 30 days birth_rate = 1 # 1 child is born per day susceptibility_rate = 1 / 30 # a child become susceptible in 20 days nsir = NSIR ( N , beta , gamma , birth_rate , susceptibility_rate ) states = nsir . solve ( n_days = 1000 ) states . show ( plotly = False )
docs.title: Adding a new born compartment

docs.text: Such models can also be used to model the dynamics of any deterministic system. For example if you want to model the famous predator-prey model, aka Fox&Rabbit model, aka Lotka-Volterra competition problem you can also use the pyepidemics library as shown below : class LotkaVolterra ( CompartmentalModel ): def __init__ ( self , alpha , beta , gamma , delta ): # Define compartments name and number compartments = [ "fox" , "rabbit" ] super () . __init__ ( compartments ) # Add transition self . add_static_derivative ( "rabbit" , lambda y , t : alpha * y [ "rabbit" ] - beta * y [ "rabbit" ] * y [ "fox" ]) self . add_static_derivative ( "fox" , lambda y , t : beta * delta * y [ "rabbit" ] * y [ "fox" ] - gamma * y [ "fox" ] ) alpha = 1. beta = 0.1 gamma = 1.5 delta = 0.75 lotka = LotkaVolterra ( alpha , beta , delta , gamma ) states = lotka . solve ( n_days = 30 , init_state = { "rabbit" : 10 , "fox" : 5 }, d = 100 ) states . show ( plotly = False )
docs.title: Modelling Fox & Rabbit populations

docs.text: There are many other parameters you can configure in custom models: I0 , the number of infected at t = 0 start_date to deal with dates and not days initial_state and start_state , start means at which state the epidemics start, for a SIR model initial_state="S" and start_state="I"
docs.title: Advanced users

docs.text: Overriding derivatives: Behind the CompartmentalModel a network is constructed and derivatives are computed using network transitions. Yet for any model you could override Adding granularity: to build models by categories (age, region) using contact matrix, it's also easy to build with pyepidemics
docs.title: Super-advanced users

docs.text: # Constants N = 1e6 # population gamma = 1 / 4 # rate of infection delta = 1 / 3 # incubation time theta = 1 / 5 # ndays before complication kappa = 1 / 10 # ndays before symptoms disappear phi = 0.5 # probability of complications alpha = 0.2 # probability to die rho = 1 / 9 # 9 ndays before death # Define the initial state exposed = 1 init_state = ( N - exposed , exposed , 0 , 0 , 0 , 0 ) # Policy simulation lockdown_after = 20 beta_high = gamma * 5 beta_low = [ gamma * 5 , gamma * 2.5 , gamma * 0.9 ] def beta_lockdown ( y , t , beta_low ): if t < lockdown_after : return beta_high else : return beta_low for b in beta_low : # Define the model seihdr = SEIHDR ( N , lambda y , t : beta_lockdown ( y , t , b ), delta , gamma , rho , alpha , theta , phi , kappa ) # Solve the equations states = seihdr . solve ( init_state , n_days = 100 ) print ( "---------------------------------------" ) print ( f "Lockdown at {lockdown_after} with R0={b/gamma}" ) states . show_peak ( show = True ) print ( f "- Max hospitals {int(states['H'].max())} at day {states['H'].idxmax()}" ) print ( "" ) --------------------------------------- Lockdown at 20 with R0=5.0 - Max hospitals 148667 at day 44 --------------------------------------- Lockdown at 20 with R0=2.5 - Max hospitals 112637 at day 57 --------------------------------------- Lockdown at 20 with R0=0.9 - Max hospitals 14464 at day 100 Let's see impact of delaying lockdown # Constants N = 1e6 # population gamma = 1 / 4 # rate of infection delta = 1 / 3 # incubation time theta = 1 / 5 # ndays before complication kappa = 1 / 10 # ndays before symptoms disappear phi = 0.5 # probability of complications alpha = 0.2 # probability to die rho = 1 / 9 # 9 ndays before death # Define the initial state exposed = 1 init_state = ( N - exposed , exposed , 0 , 0 , 0 , 0 ) # Policy simulation lockdown_after = [ 10 , 20 , 30 , 40 , 50 , 80 ] beta_high = gamma * 5 beta_low = gamma * 0.9 def beta_lockdown ( y , t , start ): if t < start : return beta_high else : return beta_low for l in lockdown_after : # Define the model seihdr = SEIHDR ( N , lambda y , t : beta_lockdown ( y , t , l ), delta , gamma , rho , alpha , theta , phi , kappa ) # Solve the equations states = seihdr . solve ( init_state , n_days = 100 ) print ( "---------------------------------------" ) print ( f "Lockdown at {l} with R0={b/gamma}" ) states . show_peak ( show = True ) print ( f "- Max hospitals {int(states['H'].max())} at day {states['H'].idxmax()}" ) print ( "" ) --------------------------------------- Lockdown at 10 with R0=0.9 - Max hospitals 639 at day 100 --------------------------------------- Lockdown at 20 with R0=0.9 - Max hospitals 14464 at day 100 --------------------------------------- Lockdown at 30 with R0=0.9 - Max hospitals 45637 at day 49 --------------------------------------- Lockdown at 40 with R0=0.9 - Max hospitals 146938 at day 44 --------------------------------------- Lockdown at 50 with R0=0.9 - Max hospitals 148667 at day 44 --------------------------------------- Lockdown at 80 with R0=0.9 - Max hospitals 148667 at day 44
docs.title: Simple lockdown policy on SEIHDR model

docs.text: To illustrate a gradual policy we will use the function below The parameter duration allows to decide how long it takes to make a 95% shift in the sigmoid, ie how long for the policy to be asymptotically implemented around the inflection point at (end - start) / 2 from covid.policies.utils import sigmoid_response from covid.policies.utils import multiple_sigmoid_response x = np . linspace ( 0 , 100 ) start = 2 end = 1 start_date = 30 plt . figure ( figsize = ( 15 , 4 )) for duration in [ 2 , 7 , 14 , 30 ]: plt . plot ( x , sigmoid_response ( x , start_date - duration / 2 , start , end , duration ), label = duration ) plt . legend () plt . show () Without offseting the inflection point, it's actually starting at the start date to simulate when a policy is implemented x = np . linspace ( 0 , 100 ) start = 2 end = 1 start_date = 30 plt . figure ( figsize = ( 15 , 4 )) for duration in [ 2 , 7 , 14 , 30 ]: plt . plot ( x , sigmoid_response ( x , start_date , start , end , duration ), label = duration ) plt . legend () plt . show () Now let's implemented this gradual lockdown policy # Constants N = 1e6 # population gamma = 1 / 4 # rate of infection delta = 1 / 3 # incubation time theta = 1 / 5 # ndays before complication kappa = 1 / 10 # ndays before symptoms disappear phi = 0.5 # probability of complications alpha = 0.2 # probability to die rho = 1 / 9 # 9 ndays before death # Define the initial state infected = 1 init_state = ( N - infected , 0 , infected , 0 , 0 , 0 ) # Policy simulation lockdown_after = [ 10 , 20 , 25 , 30 , 35 , 40 ] beta_high = gamma * 5 beta_low = gamma * 0.9 lockdown_implementation_days = 6 def beta_lockdown ( y , t , l ): return sigmoid_response ( t , l , beta_high , beta_low , lockdown_implementation_days ) for l in lockdown_after : # Define the model seihdr = SEIHDR ( N , lambda y , t : beta_lockdown ( y , t , l ), delta , gamma , rho , alpha , theta , phi , kappa ) # Solve the equations states = seihdr . solve ( init_state , n_days = 100 ) print ( "---------------------------------------" ) print ( f "Lockdown at day {l} with R0={b/gamma}" ) states . show_peak () print ( f "- Max hospitals {int(states['H'].max())} at day {states['H'].idxmax()}" ) print ( "" ) --------------------------------------- Lockdown at day 10 with R0=0.9 - Max hospitals 4201 at day 100 --------------------------------------- Lockdown at day 20 with R0=0.9 - Max hospitals 23402 at day 80 --------------------------------------- Lockdown at day 25 with R0=0.9 - Max hospitals 48029 at day 47 --------------------------------------- Lockdown at day 30 with R0=0.9 - Max hospitals 113411 at day 41 --------------------------------------- Lockdown at day 35 with R0=0.9 - Max hospitals 145902 at day 42 --------------------------------------- Lockdown at day 40 with R0=0.9 - Max hospitals 148631 at day 42
docs.title: Gradual lockdown policy with sigmoid

docs.text: For the exit strategy we need a double sigmoid, we will use the multiple_sigmoid_response function We can build complex response curves x = np . linspace ( 0 , 100 ) start_value = 2 values = [ 1 , 0.2 , 3 , 1.5 ] dates = [ 10 , 30 , 50 , 80 ] durations = [ 3 , 10 , 11 , 4 ] y = multiple_sigmoid_response ( x , start_value , values , dates , durations ) plt . figure ( figsize = ( 15 , 4 )) plt . plot ( x , y ) plt . show () For an exit strategy we model a beta that go up again when the lockdown is finished x = np . linspace ( 0 , 100 ) start_value = 2 values = [ 0.5 , 2 ] dates = [ 30 , 90 ] durations = 5 y = multiple_sigmoid_response ( x , start_value , values , dates , durations ) plt . figure ( figsize = ( 15 , 4 )) plt . plot ( x , y ) plt . show () Let's put this function in the SEIHDR model # Constants N = 1e6 # population gamma = 1 / 4 # rate of infection delta = 1 / 3 # incubation time theta = 1 / 5 # ndays before complication kappa = 1 / 10 # ndays before symptoms disappear phi = 0.5 # probability of complications alpha = 0.2 # probability to die rho = 1 / 9 # 9 ndays before death # Define the initial state exposed = 1 init_state = ( N - exposed , exposed , 0 , 0 , 0 , 0 ) # Policy simulation lockdown_after = 25 beta_high = gamma * 5 beta_low = gamma * 0.9 betas = [ beta_low , beta_high ] lockdown_implementation_days = 6 def beta_lockdown ( y , t , exit ): return multiple_sigmoid_response ( t , beta_high , betas ,[ lockdown_after , exit ], lockdown_implementation_days ) for duration in [ 120 , 90 , 60 , 30 , 10 ]: exit = lockdown_after + duration # Define the model seihdr = SEIHDR ( N , lambda y , t : beta_lockdown ( y , t , exit ), delta , gamma , rho , alpha , theta , phi , kappa ) # Solve the equations states = seihdr . solve ( init_state , n_days = 200 ) print ( "---------------------------------------" ) print ( f "Lockdown at day {lockdown_after} with R0={b/gamma} for {duration} days" ) states . show_peak ( show = False ) plt . axvline ( x = lockdown_after , lw = 3 , color = "red" ) plt . axvline ( x = exit , lw = 3 , color = "red" ) plt . show () print ( f "- Max hospitals {int(states['H'].max())} at day {states['H'].idxmax()}" ) print ( "" ) --------------------------------------- Lockdown at day 25 with R0=0.9 for 120 days - Max hospitals 33140 at day 59 --------------------------------------- Lockdown at day 25 with R0=0.9 for 90 days - Max hospitals 34671 at day 147 --------------------------------------- Lockdown at day 25 with R0=0.9 for 60 days - Max hospitals 52026 at day 107 --------------------------------------- Lockdown at day 25 with R0=0.9 for 30 days - Max hospitals 100823 at day 72 --------------------------------------- Lockdown at day 25 with R0=0.9 for 10 days - Max hospitals 137364 at day 52
docs.title: Simple lockdown exit strategy

docs.text: import networkx as nx pos = nx . spectral_layout ( seidr . network . graph ) pos {'S': array([ 9.93364820e-01, -3.16250152e-16]), 'E': array([ 4.78001493e-01, -9.42055475e-17]), 'I': array([-2.85351731e-01, 1.27839057e-16]), 'D': array([-0.59300729, -1. ]), 'R': array([-0.59300729, 1. ])} A = np . array ( list ( pos . values ())) def create_angle ( pos ): A = np . array ( list ( pos . values ())) th = np . arctan2 ( * ( A [ 1 ] - A [ 0 ])) - np . pi * 0.5 c = np . cos ( th ) s = np . sin ( th ) th = np . array ([[ c , - s ],[ s , c ]]) return th A2 = A . dot ( create_angle ( pos ) . T ) pos2 = { k : A2 [ i ] for i , k in enumerate ( "SEIDR" )} pos2 {'S': array([-9.93364820e-01, -2.46544551e-16]), 'E': array([-4.78001493e-01, -1.76608058e-16]), 'I': array([2.85351731e-01, 3.38280757e-17]), 'D': array([0.59300729, 1. ]), 'R': array([ 0.59300729, -1. ])} nx . draw_spectral ( seidr . network . graph ) nx . draw ( seidr . network . graph , pos = pos2 ) from covid.models.network import CompartmentNetwork G = CompartmentNetwork ([ "S" , "I" , "R" ]) G . compute_derivatives ([ "S" , "I" , "R" ], 1 , 1 ) [0, 0, 0] G . add_edge ( "S" , "I" , 1 , 1 , lambda y , t : t ) G . get_transition ( "S" , "I" , None , 3 ) 3 G . show () G . get_derivative ( "R" ) -1 f = lambda y , t : 1 def test ( y , t ): return 1 callable ( test ) True
